Monsieur 1© ’'inistre T have the honour to inform Your Excellency that I have received a comminication from the Ministry of Justice draving my attention to a criminal case i hich has arisen at Changvad Ubol and in vhich an Indian British subject named A’<a Pasa is being prosecuted on a charge of assault committed on an Annamite French subject named Ngian-Vanchao. As the accused is a British subject, the case \ ould, in the ordinary course, have to be tried by the Siamese Competent Court. But the injured man to whose detriment the offence was committed being a French subject under the Jurisdiction Protocol annexed to the Treaty bet^ een France and Siam the case would have to come under the juris diction of the International Court. The question therefore arises in which of these Courts the case should be tried. The Ministry of Justice is of the opinion that in all cases where the jurisdictional right under the Treaties of the plaintiff or aggrieved party is in conflict with that of the defendant or accused, the right of the latter alone should be considered in deciding the jurisdiction of the Court over the case and the procedure to be followed and in this particular case, I am informed, Judge Buszard has informally obtained the concurrence of your legation to have the case tried in the Siamese Competent Court, and so far as the French Legation is concerned no objection was raised to this procedure. 4 . His Excellency Monsieur Cecil F.J. Dormer. His Britannic Majesty’s Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary* Bangkok* AsAs this solution seems to be quite satisfactory to all concerned the 'finistry of Justice proposes that it be adopted as a rule in the future. Accordingly, it is proposed that in all under the Treat 3 the parties concerned are subject to the Jurisdiction of different Courts the Jurisdictional right of the defendant or accused alone shall be l\ considered in deciding the Jurisdiction of the Court over the case as well as the procedure to be followed, without regard to the right of other parties concerned. I shall be much obliged to be informed if there is any objection on the part of your Legation to the above rule being adopted. I avail myself of this opportunity, Monsieur le Ministre, to renew to Your Kxcellency the assurance of my highest consideration. (Sgd) Phya Srivisar. Whereas by a Protocol signed, on July 14th, 1925, on behalf of His Majesty and His Majesty the King of Siam provision was made for the cessation and determination of the system of jurisdiction heretofore established in Siam for British subjects and the privileges, exemptions and immunities now enjoyed by British subjects in Siam : And whereas it was further provided by the said Protocol that for the period therein prescribed the jurisdiction of His Majesty’s diplomatic and consular officials in Siam should con tinue for the purpose of trying cases evoked from the Siamese Courts in accordance with the said Protocol, and of executing any judgments which may be rendered therein : And whereas accordingly by Treaty, capitulation, grant, usage, sufferance and other lawful means His Majesty the King has jurisdiction within the dominions of the King of Siam : Now, therefore, His Majesty, by virtue and in exercise of the powers in this behalf by the Foreign Jurisdiction Acts, 1890 and 1913, (a; or otherwise in His Majesty vested, is pleased, by and with the advice of His Privy Council, to order, and it is hereby ordered, as follows :— 1. This Order may be cited as “ The Siam Order in Council, 1926,” and shall be read as one with the ” Siam Order in Council 1914.”(to in this Order referred to as ” The Principal Order.' (3) Siamese subjects and foreigners in the cases and according to the conditions specified in this Order, and not otherwise. (4t Foreigners, with respect to whom any State, King, Chief or Government, whose subjects or under whose protection they are, has by any Treaty as herein defined or otherwise agreed with His Majesty for, or consents to, the exercise of power or authority by His Majesty. “ (5) British ships with their boats, and the persons and property on board thereof, or belonging thereto, being within the Siamese dominions.” Article 5. All Plis Majesty’s jurisdiction exercisable in k lain for the hearing and determination of civil matters or < ivil or criminal cases, or for the maintenance of order, or for the control or administration of persons or property or in relation thereto, shall be exercised under and according to the provisions of this Order and not otherwise.” Article 9.—Subject to the provisions of this Order, criminal and civil cases may be tried by the Court itself, or by the Court with a jury or with assessors.”“ Article 11.—W here a case is transferred to the Court from a Siamese Court, the Court shall give such directions as seem proper for its determination, having regard to the proceedings (if any) in the Siamese Court. In determining such case, the Court shall apply English law and practice for the time being, except that, as to all matters coming within the scope of codes or laws of the Kingdom of Siam regularly promulgated and in force, the texts of which have been communicated to His Majesty’s Legation, such Siamese codes or laws shall be applied.” ” Article 32.—(i) Where any case in which a Siamese or foreigner is plaintiff or complainant is transferred to the Court from any Siamese Court, the Court shall hear and determine the case in all respects according to the ordinary course of the Court.” 3. Every male resident British subject of the age of 21 years or upwards, having a competent knowledge of the English language, and having or earning a gross income of such amount as may be determined by Buies of Court, and not having been attainted of treason or felony, or convicted of any crime that is infamous (unless he has obtained a free pardon), or being under outlawry, shall be qualified to serve on a jury. 4. The Schedule hereto is hereby substituted for the Schedule to the Principal Order. 5. W^here a British subject is accused of the commission of an offence the cognizance whereof appertains to the Court, and it is expedient that the offence be inquired of, tried, determined, and punished in a British possession, the accused may (under the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1890, Section 6) be sent for trial to the Straits Settlements. The Court may, where it appears so expedient, by warrant under the seal of the Court, cause the accused to be sent for trial to the Straits Settlements accordingly. The warrant shall be sufficient authority to any person to whom it is directed to receive and detain the person therein named, and to carry him to and deliver him up to the Straits Settlements. Where any person is to be so sent to the Straits Settlements, the Court before which he is charged shall take the preliminary examination, and shall bind over such of the proper witnesses as are British subjects in their ow r n recognizances to appear and give evidence on the trial. 6. —(1) Where an offender is sentenced to imprisonment, and the Court thinks it expedient that the sentence be carried into effect within His Majesty’s dominions, and the offender is accordingly under Section 7 of the Foreign Jurisdiction Act, 1890, 19848sent for imprisonment to a place in His Majesty’s dominions, the place shall be either Singapore, Rangoon or Calcutta, or a place in some other part of His Majesty’s dominions out of the United Kingdom, the Government whereof consents that offenders may be sent thither under this Article. (•2) Hie Court may, by warrant under the seal of the Court, cause the offender to be sent to Singapore, Rangoon or Calcutta, or such other place as aforesaid, in order that the sentence may be there Carried into effect accordingly. (3) The warrant shall be sufficient authority to any person to whom it is directed to receive and detain the person therein mined and to carry him to and deliver him up at the place named, according to the warrant. 7. W here any person is sentenced by the Court to suffer the punishment of death, the Court shall forthwith send a report of the sentence, with a copy of the Minutes of Proceedings and notes of evidence in the case, and with any observations it thinks fit, to the Minister. physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the back to the front.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 62; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: Correspondence, notes, and minute papers concerning The Siam Order in Council, 1926. The papers cover the inter-departmental discussion over both the drafting of the original Order in Council (in 1926) and the procedure to be followed in cases where involved parties are subject to different courts (French and British, in this instance).Correspondents include officials at the India Office, Foreign Office, Colonial Office, Dominions Office, Government of India (Foreign and Political Department), and the British Legation in Bangkok.
